ticket.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue
ticket.original-body:
The result of to_json command evolved between 2.3.3 and 2.3.4 , breaking my web app :
New behaviour :
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\"attributes\":{...snip...},\"json_class\":\"Event\",\"attributes_cache\":{}}"
Old behaviour :
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\"event\":{...snip...}"
I am using the json gem for json processing in rails as introduced in rails 2.3.3 : In my environment.rb there is this line : ActiveSupport::JSON.backend = 'JSONGem'
But I also tried with default json support and the behaviour is the same.

But I also tried with default json support and the behaviour is the same.

version.body:
The result of to_json command evolved between 2.3.3 and 2.3.4 , breaking my web app :
New behaviour : @@@ Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\\"attributes\\":{...snip...},\\"json_class\\":\\"Event\\",\\"attributes_cache\\":{}}" @@@ Old behaviour : @@@ Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\\"event\\":{...snip...}" @@@ I am using the json gem for json processing in rails as introduced in rails 2.3.3 : In my environment.rb there is this line : ActiveSupport::JSON.backend = 'JSONGem'
But I also tried with default json support and the behaviour is the same.
version.body-html:
The result of to_json command evolved between 2.3.3 and 2.3.4 , breaking my web app :

New behaviour :

Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4)
>> Event.find(9).to_json
=> "{\"attributes\":{...snip...},\"json_class\":\"Event\",\"attributes_cache\":{}}"
Old behaviour :
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3)
>> Event.find(9).to_json
=> "{\"event\":{...snip...}"
I am using the json gem for json processing in rails as introduced in rails 2.3.3 :
In my environment.rb there is this line : ActiveSupport::JSON.backend = 'JSONGem'

But I also tried with default json support and the behaviour is the same.
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
looks invalid to me:
$ sc Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Item.new.to_json SQL (0.1ms) SET SQL_AUTO_IS_NULL=0 Item Columns (2.0ms) SHOW FIELDS FROM `items` => "{"item":{"created_at":null,"updated_at":null}}" >> exit
$ sc Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Item.new.to_json SQL (0.2ms) SET SQL_AUTO_IS_NULL=0 Item Columns (1.7ms) SHOW FIELDS FROM `items` => "{"item":{"created_at":null,"updated_at":null}}"

version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
@@@ Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Item.new.to_json => "{\"item\":{\"created_at\":null,\"updated_at\":null}}" @@@
@@@ Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Item.new.to_json => "{\"item\":{\"created_at\":null,\"updated_at\":null}}" @@@
-1 ,going to say invalid.
version.body-html:
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4)
>> Item.new.to_json
=> "{\"item\":{\"created_at\":null,\"updated_at\":null}}"

Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3)
>> Item.new.to_json
=> "{\"item\":{\"created_at\":null,\"updated_at\":null}}"

-1 ,going to say invalid.
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
-1, not reproducible.
Looks to me like there's no difference between 2.3.3 and 2.3.4:
@@@ ts > ruby script/console Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Event.new(:name => "test", :when => 2.days.from_now).to_json => "{\"event\":{\"name\":\"test\",\"updated_at\":null,\"when\":\"2009-09-28T21:08:03Z\",\"created_at\":null}}"
ts > ruby script/console Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Event.new(:name => "test", :when => 2.days.from_now).to_json => "{\"event\":{\"name\":\"test\",\"updated_at\":null,\"when\":\"2009-09-28T21:08:27Z\",\"created_at\":null}}" @@@
version.body-html:
-1, not reproducible.

Looks to me like there's no difference between 2.3.3 and 2.3.4:

ts > ruby script/console 
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3)
>> Event.new(:name => "test", :when => 2.days.from_now).to_json
=> "{\"event\":{\"name\":\"test\",\"updated_at\":null,\"when\":\"2009-09-28T21:08:03Z\",\"created_at\":null}}"

ts > ruby script/console 
Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4)
>> Event.new(:name => "test", :when => 2.days.from_now).to_json
=> "{\"event\":{\"name\":\"test\",\"updated_at\":null,\"when\":\"2009-09-28T21:08:27Z\",\"created_at\":null}}"

version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
This bug is reproducible:
No json or json_pure gem installed in the system:
`Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\"event\":{...snip...}"`
After "gem install json":
`Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4) >> Event.find(9).to_json => "{\"attributes\":{...snip...},\"json_class\":\"Event\",\"attributes_cache\":{}}"`
version.body-html:
This bug is reproducible:

No json or json_pure gem installed in the system:

Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.3)

Event.find(9).to_json => "{">event

After "gem install json":

Loading development environment (Rails 2.3.4)

Event.find(9).to_json => "{">attributes

version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
I am also having an issue with to_json that is very reproducible. This is 1.0 compliant JSON: {"location": [{"name":"ER","city":"chicago","address1":"tvland","zip":"60601","created_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:07Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:07Z","id":1,"lat":"","state":"IL","long":""},{"name":"st. elsewhere","city":"chicago","address1":"tvland","zip":"60601","created_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:43Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:43Z","id":2,"lat":"","state":"IL","long":""},{"name":"MASH","city":"seoul","address1":"tvland","zip":"somezip","created_at":"2009-11-15T17:24:45Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T17:24:45Z","id":3,"lat":"","state":"korea","long":""}] }
This is what freshly compiled Rails 2.3.4 produces (no pure_json or json installed) from a call to my locations model @Locations = Location.all.to_json: [{"name":"ER","city":"chicago","address1":"tvland","zip":"60601","created_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:07Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:07Z","id":1,"lat":"","state":"IL","long":""},{"name":"st. elsewhere","city":"chicago","address1":"tvland","zip":"60601","created_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:43Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T16:50:43Z","id":2,"lat":"","state":"IL","long":""},{"name":"MASH","city":"seoul","address1":"tvland","zip":"somezip","created_at":"2009-11-15T17:24:45Z","address2":"tvland","updated_at":"2009-11-15T17:24:45Z","id":3,"lat":"","state":"korea","long":""}]
The enclosing brackets cause the json library not to correctly parse the json string.
Then as_json give this:
<Location:0x28357f0>#<Location:0x2835674>#<Location:0x2835624>
Something is wrong here.
version.body-html:
I am also having an issue with to_json that is very reproducible. This is 1.0 compliant JSON:
{"location": [{city }

This is what freshly compiled Rails 2.3.4 produces (no pure_json or json installed) from a call to my locations model @Locations = Location.all.to_json: [{city

The enclosing brackets cause the json library not to correctly parse the json string.

Then as_json give this:

<Location:0x28357f0>#<Location:0x2835674>#<Location:0x2835624>

Something is wrong here.

version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
I have the same problem.
Removing the json gem dependancy from environment.rb fixes the problem. Unfortunately that's not feasible for me since I am using other gems that depend on the json gem. Bummer.
In addition to the problems stated above, the problem also affects the :include, and :except options. This problem is also present in Rails 2.3.5
Could someone please remove the 'invalid' status?
version.body-html:
I have the same problem.

Removing the json gem dependancy from environment.rb fixes the problem. Unfortunately that's not feasible for me since I am using other gems that depend on the json gem. Bummer.

In addition to the problems stated above, the problem also affects the :include, and :except options.
This problem is also present in Rails 2.3.5

Could someone please remove the 'invalid' status?
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body: Can somebody please provide a patch for this?
version.body-html: Can somebody please provide a patch for this?
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
To fix, you need to explicitly require the json gem in config/environment.rb so Rails can override its choice of to_json implementation.
In Rails 3, we explicitly load the json gem if present then neuter its to_json. This approach can be backported to 2-3-stable.
version.body-html:
To fix, you need to explicitly require the json gem in config/environment.rb so Rails can override its choice of to_json implementation.

In Rails 3, we explicitly load the json gem if present then neuter its to_json. This approach can be backported to 2-3-stable.
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body: To confirm the approach followed in Rails 3. The approach is to move the json code to ActiveModel::Serializers::JSON, and make sure to NOT use the json gem if is is present? Where is this code? Also, the serializer in ActiveModel doesn't have to_json, right? Where is the code to override the json gem? (I am new to contributing to rails core but want to help out so please be nice ;-)
version.body-html: To confirm the approach followed in Rails 3. The approach is to move the json code to ActiveModel::Serializers::JSON, and make sure to NOT use the json gem if is is present? Where is this code? Also, the serializer in ActiveModel doesn't have to_json, right? Where is the code to override the json gem? (I am new to contributing to rails core but want to help out so please be nice ;-)
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
The JSON code you're looking for is in active_support/json, not Active Model or Record :)
See active_support/json/encoding.rb in git master.
version.body-html:
The JSON code you're looking for is in active_support/json, not Active Model or Record :)

See active_support/json/encoding.rb in git master.
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body: For me it was the contacts gem (http://github.com/mislav/contacts), which broke the to_json method. See the ticket on Github: http://github.com/mislav/contacts/issues/issue/3
version.body-html: For me it was the contacts gem (http://github.com/mislav/contacts), which broke the to_json method. See the ticket on Github: http://github.com/mislav/contacts/issues/issue/3

version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
I've been upgrading our app from Rails 2.2.2 to 2.3.8 and hit this problem (and all sorts of other JSON craziness). I was stumped, changing ActiveSupport::JSON.backend in environment.rb was giving me no love. I eventually tracked down the source to a require of 'json/add/rails', which we were including so that we could hack the way JSON::Ext::Generator::State worked.
So, if you're hitting this problem the one thing you may want to do is search your codebase for a require of 'json/add/rails'... worked for me.
version.body-html:
I've been upgrading our app from Rails 2.2.2 to 2.3.8 and hit this problem (and all sorts of other JSON craziness). I was stumped, changing ActiveSupport::JSON.backend in environment.rb was giving me no love. I eventually tracked down the source to a require of 'json/add/rails', which we were including so that we could hack the way JSON::Ext::Generator::State worked.

So, if you're hitting this problem the one thing you may want to do is search your codebase for a require of 'json/add/rails'... worked for me.
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body:
Heh, I spoke too soon...
For objects from classes that descend from ActiveRecord::Base removing the 'json/add/rails'require was all that was needed to get back to vanilla to_json. However, oddly, once I remove 'json/add/rails', if I leave in 'json/add/core' then non-AR::Base objects start to jsonize oddly:
@@@ ruby # without 'json/add/rails', with 'json/add/core' >> {:foo => :bar}.to_json => "{\"foo\":{\"json_class\":\"Symbol\",\"s\":\"bar\"}}"
# (without 'json/add/rails', without 'json/add/core') OR (with 'json/add/rails', with 'json/add/core') >> {:foo => :bar}.to_json => "{\"foo\":{\"json_class\":\"Symbol\",\"s\":\"bar\"}}" @@@
version.body-html:
Heh, I spoke too soon...

For objects from classes that descend from ActiveRecord::Base removing the 'json/add/rails'require was all that was needed to get back to vanilla to_json. However, oddly, once I remove 'json/add/rails', if I leave in 'json/add/core' then non-AR::Base objects start to jsonize oddly:

# without 'json/add/rails', with 'json/add/core'
>> {:foo => :bar}.to_json
=> "{\"foo\":{\"json_class\":\"Symbol\",\"s\":\"bar\"}}"

# (without 'json/add/rails', without 'json/add/core') OR (with 'json/add/rails', with 'json/add/core')
>> {:foo => :bar}.to_json
=> "{\"foo\":{\"json_class\":\"Symbol\",\"s\":\"bar\"}}"
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body: updating the contacts gem solved my problem (rails 2.3.8, contacts 1.2.3)
version.body-html: updating the contacts gem solved my problem (rails 2.3.8, contacts 1.2.3)
version.title: Rails 2.3.4, json gem : to_json issue

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
